body.div1:
In the United States Circuit Court District of Washington, Northern Division
In the matter of the Petition of H. C. Littooy for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
United States of America State of Washington
<<<<<<< Updated upstream =======
Samuel R. Stern being duly sworn says that he has represented the State of Washington in the case numbered 3076 referred to in the petition herein and prosecuted this said defendant under the information referred to in said petition.
That a trial was had in June 23, 1904 and in a verdict of guilty. That defendant though has Counsel Parker & Brown have served a motion for a new trial and with arrest of judgement and have that they intend to appeal at the Supreme Court of the State of Washington in the event that said motion is remanded.
Defendant further says that the warrant issued herein was executed by the Sheriff of the County as follows:
One of his deputies is informed the defendant that he had a warrant for his arrest whereupon the firm of Parker & Brown as his attorneys arranged with one of the deputy Prosecuting Attorneys that they would appear for said defendant, enter a plea of not guilty and try the case in June 20, 1904 where so-called dental laws were to be called for trial before Judge C. H. Hanford setting in the criminal department. That bails has been given so far as the reason the Sheriff's office in Clerk's Office show that the defendant has never prior to the command of the writ herein been in custody. That a return was issued to Mr. the office deputy and the Sheriff of King County in this June 27, 1904, and he was requested for said Sheriff before the same but refused to do so but instead notified the attorney by the said defendant that he should come to the Sheriff's office.
Defendant further says that no attempt has been made by the Sheriff's office in any therein the Prosecuting Attorney's Office to deprive said petitioner of his liberty and he has not been deprived of his liberty at any time and has not been detained against his will under the fact that he now in Court can be so construed.
Defendant further says that there has been no attempt to deprive this defendant of his property and his liberty. That he has been prosecuted for three several distinct poffenses against said dental laws and no taht there are 6 or 8 informative files against and as others have been prosecuted and not otherwise he has been violating said law and said prosecution has had deponents personal attention. He knows of these facts of his own personal knowledge
Defendant further says that in the case of this State of Washington against O. J. Thompson a conviction has been had under the so called Dental Law and an appeal has been made to the Supreme Court of the State of Washington by this same counsel for the appeal for this petitioner here and the questionof the Constitutionality of said law has been raised in said appeal, which said appeal was argued several weeks ago and Counsel for said appelant has informed the Supreme Court of King County in several when they by the trials of defendants informed of a writ under said Dental Law that they were promised by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court a careful review of all questions involved in said appeal.
this June 27, 1904
Paul Rettani
H. M. Matthew
Deputy Clerk, U. S. Circuit Court, District of Washington. >>>>>>> Stashed changes
No. 1207
IN THE Circuit COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON
In re - H. C. Littoy Habeas Corpus
Affidavit of Samuel R. Stern -
Filed June 28, 1904
A. Reeves Ayres, Clerk
By A. N. Moore, Deputy
